page.title: 08The Staffs-Worcester Canal
page.content: The Staffs-Worcester Canal was built in 1782 by James Brindley.It is one of the first canals in the country.It runs from the River Severn at Stourport to the Trent Mersey Navigation at Great Heywood. It was built to carry coal,limestone and other heavy goods,and to join the Severn to the Trent,both of which were major routeways in the eighteenth century. The lock weirs on the Staffs-Worcester canal are unique.The weirs are away from the gates so that when the lock is filled the boat does not get pushed about by the water which is flowing in. Locks like these are at Swindon, Hinksford and Greensforge. Today the canal is mainly used for pleasure.People go for holidays on boats and anglers fish in it.There is a marina at Ashwood (see separate entry) where boats are berthed.
